title: Between 1 April 2018 and 31 March 2019, will an armed group from Burundi engage in a campaign that systematically kills 1,000 or more civilians in Burundi?
preds: A referendum allowing President Pierre Nkurunziza to avail himself to two more terms in office passed with 73% of the vote, as expected. Despite multiple incidents of violence and intimidation by the president's supporters before the vote, the aftermath has been relatively calm thus far. Also as expected, the opposition Amizero y’Abarundi has refused to accept the outcome. Yesterday they filed a petition with Burundi's Constitutional Court to annul the results.  A major concern of those who oppose the referendum is that, in addition to allowing the ruling party to strengthen its hold on power, it will allow the government to revise the system of ethnic quotas that were agreed upon as part of the Arusha Accords that ended the country's 13 year civil war. Like neighboring Rwanda, Burundi underwent a brutal war that pitted Hutu and against Tutsi. In the past, Nkurunziza's political machinations have led to an attempted coup and violent crackdowns on political protests.  In a sign that the government feels confident in its position domestically, discussions to end a 6-month-long ban on the BBC and VOA are underway.  https://www.independent.co.ug/burundi-opposition-goes-to-court-over-referendum-result/ https://abcnews.go.com/US/wireStory/envoy-urges-dialogue-opposition-burundi-vote-55423674 http://www.iwacu-burundi.org/referendum-la-coalition-amizero-yabarundi-porte-plainte/ http://allafrica.com/stories/201805240383.html
Yes, but will not break the 1000 civilian death mark.

A referendum on May 18 in which President Pierre Nkurunziza will extend his term in office until 2034 is a potential flashpoint (it goes without saying that a "yes" win is a foregone conclusion...the vote will be neither free nor fair),  Some incidents of violence have been reported and a pro-government figure was recently jailed for threatening to drown opponents of the referndum.  http://www.irinnews.org/analysis/2018/05/03/burundi-disputed-referendum-threatens-deepen-neglected-humanitarian-crisis

Although conditions appear to be conducive towards violence and instability, all is calm for the moment. Last year the government released political prisoners and the president went abroad for the first time following 2015 coup attempt. This would indicate the government is confident in its position but regional spillover, weak institutions, and repression remain points of concern

Of all the countries in the challenge that could hit 1000 civilian deaths, Burundi would be it.  But between 2015-2016 there were a total of just 720.  Something major would need to occur to escalate the unrest.  https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-04-26/burundi-unrest-leaves-720-people-dead-in-two-years-group-says
